results.summary: A man is to be charged with murdering 16-year-old Christina Edkins, who was stabbed to death on a bus in Birmingham.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/f0505be0-7d58-ce4d-b36e-d70d09519b01"><image id="66252167"/><paragraph role="introduction">A man arrested over the fatal stabbing of a 16-year-old girl on a bus is to be charged with murder, police have said. </paragraph><paragraph>Christina Edkins was stabbed on a bus on Hagley Road in Birmingham on Thursday, on her way to school in Halesowen.</paragraph><paragraph>Police said they would formally charge Phillip Simelane, 22, in the "near future" following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. </paragraph><paragraph>Christina's parents said her death had left them "heartbroken".</paragraph><paragraph>In a statement released by police, Kathleen and Jason Edkins said she was "bubbly, beautiful and intelligent". </paragraph><crosshead>'Amazing individual'</crosshead><paragraph>They added: "We are heartbroken by the loss of our beautiful princess, Christina, and it's hard to find words to describe the pain we're all feeling.</paragraph><paragraph>"Her family and friends will remember her as an amazing individual with her whole life ahead of her.</paragraph><paragraph>"A life that was tragically cut short on that Thursday morning. Our lives will never be the same again."</paragraph><image id="66270998"/><paragraph>A post-mortem examination revealed the teenager died from a single stab wound to her chest.</paragraph><paragraph>An inquest into her death is due to be opened and adjourned at Birmingham Coroner's Court on Thursday.</paragraph><paragraph>On Friday Mr Simelane, from Walsall, West Midlands, was sectioned under the Mental Health Act.</paragraph><paragraph>Hundreds of flowers and tributes were left outside Leasowes High School in Halesowen, where Christina was a pupil.</paragraph><paragraph>Counsellors were brought in to support pupils and staff after the teenager's death. </paragraph></body>
